Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of which there are sixteen in the head: two pulsating veins, which are behind the ears, called the Hermes; and two arteries, which are visible in both temporal regions; and two veins which are in the lacrimal bones of both eyes, called the Aspiring; and a vein prepared in the middle of the forehead; and a vein which is at the tip of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two guides, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins that are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins that are called Algieric.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins that are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	However, the veins that are bled in the arms, there are five veins in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is cephalic, and it is from the lateral side of the skull; and the common people call it the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And fusca.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And it is the median vein, and it is composed of the branch of the basilic and the branch of the cephalic; and the common people call it the body's vein.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And basilic, and it is situated on the inner side of the arm; and it is also called titillar.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And the common people call it the stomach's vein.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the vein of the arm (funis), and it is situated above the elbow; and it is through this that bleeding is done, and it is the one that is visible above the thumb with a manifest appearance.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the little vein: it is the vein that lies between the ring finger and the little finger, and it has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And in the leg and foot there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is located beneath the bend of the thumb on the lateral side of the wrist.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is the Saphenous vein, and it is located near the heel on the outer side of the body.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the vein of the foot: its location is near the heel on the outer side of the wrist.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And there are three other veins in the leg similar to these.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	§ On phlebotomy after drawing blood from two veins near the ear.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The true phlebotomy of the two veins near the ear is indicated for chronic catarrh, hemigranae (half-headache), old skin ulcers, and other ancient head conditions.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the phlebotomy depends on what I have described.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is done by purging the head from below: and the nape of the neck is rubbed at the location of the two veins with a rough cloth using proper friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then he strains his weakened neck with a twist, until two veins become visible.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And the locations of these are behind the ears in two depressed areas of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Therefore, seek them out with your finger, and where you feel the pulsation of these veins beneath your finger, mark them with cautery.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the phlebotomist's knife, which is called the "Incidens.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then insert the tip beneath the vein into the skin, until the phlebotomist reaches the vein near the mouth.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then raise your hand with the vein and skin towards the upper parts, and cut the vein with a precise incision made by the knife.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And the length of the incision should be about the size of two joined fingers, or somewhat more; and let as much blood flow out as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then tie it off with small threads, and leave it until it heals.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And this is the beginning of the book, describing the incision and cauterization of these veins.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	On the bleeding of two arteries at different times.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	The true aid for the bleeding of two arteries at different times, which is for an old migraine: and a sudden and continuous constriction; and the flow of sharp excess fluids to the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of bleeding them is according as I tell thee.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	He strains his weak neck until two veins appear to the senses with a manifest appearance, and you can feel their pulse under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then indeed, mark the signs with wax.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then take the skin above the vein with your index finger, insert the phlebotomy instrument from below, and draw the vein upwards.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut it, as you did with the other two veins: and let the blood flow according to the amount necessary for thee.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then loosen the constriction of the weak neck, and place your finger over the vein at once.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Afterwards, place a bandage and poultices over it, and tighten the constriction firmly above; and release it until it is healed.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And now let us recall those things, and their incision, and their extraction at the beginning of this book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	§ On the venesection of the forehead after the cephalic venesection.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The true instrument for venesection of the forehead is indeed after the cephalic venesection, for ancient facial ailments: and for hemicranias, and redness; and foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of that venesection is, according to what I am telling you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The weak neck is compressed with the blade until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument called the "Fossor".
Cuius haec est forma.	The form of which is as follows:
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the sharp point that is on top of the "Fossor" (instrument) against the vein itself, and strike it with a sawing motion, or with another tool in its manner: and let the blood flow according to your will.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then open the lower incision, and bind it until it heals.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And sometimes it is opened with a scalpel on the side.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	However, it is not necessary for the scalpel to have a sharp point as in other scalpels; on the contrary, it should have a broad edge.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And the scalpel should be placed on it according to its thickness, since the wound is close, and perhaps the scalpel might break when it is too thin.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	§ On the phlebotomy of veins in two places (lacrimal bones).
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The treatment of the two veins that are in the two lacrimal bones of both eyes is for the eye's inflammation and redness, as well as for conditions in the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is such that it tightens the weak neck with bloodletting.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then the scalpel should be used on them, and you should stand over their head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And the phlebotomy should be made according to the thickness, with a small scalpel, slightly broad, since there is no need for it to be deep at that place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If the scalpel is too thin, it might break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then make it flow from blood as much as is necessary for you.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And place a bandage over them, and bind them tightly at night, and loosen them in the morning.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	§ On the phlebotomy of nasal veins.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The phlebotomy of nasal veins refers to the treatment for acute fever, a violent headache, and facial pains, such as hemicranias, and the redness that occurs on the face, especially when it is chronic.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is such that it tightens the patient's neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then hold the nose with your left hand, and take a thin, long phlebotomy instrument; fix it in the middle of the nose, between what distinguishes the nose according to its straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Since the vein does not appear there to the eye, and since the blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And you must, while holding the phlebotomy instrument with your last hand, let the blood flow as much as is necessary for you.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind it tightly at night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	It is indeed quickly restored.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	**On the venesection of arteries (from Guide's manual)**
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	In Guide's manual, the true principle of venesection is to constrict the flow of blood, prevent the onset of leprosy, alleviate melancholy, treat impetigo and bad ulcers, and counteract corrosive (i.e., worm) infections.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of this venesection is that it constricts the patient under both sides of his neck with a ligature; and the surgeon should stand over the patient's head, while the patient sits on a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then the surgeon should make the venesection vein longer for a broader cut.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then extract a moderately tempered amount of blood, or according to what you see is necessary for that.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do the same for the other vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then release the ligature and tie the two veins with a medium tightness so as not to cause further harm to the patient.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And leave it until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	The wound is healed.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	On the bleeding of veins, Albucasis.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	According to Albucasis, the indication for phlebotomy of veins is when there is a buildup of blood in the mouth, leading to gum corruption, bad ulcers, and cracks in the lips and mouth, as well as those found in the nose and its surroundings.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is such that you make the patient sit before you and tighten their neck with a strap.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then you open the patient's lips and look at two veins, one on the right side of the lip and the second on the left, and their demonstration is through the darkening of the colors.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And the truth is that around them there are small, black veins.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Therefore, make an incision on each with a cutting instrument.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	If, however, there is doubt about which one it is and you do not know, then turn your attention to the larger incision and those that are more apparent.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And similarly, do the same with the two veins that are in the upper lip, and indeed custom usually follows this, and make incisions on the two veins that are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	On phlebotomy of the vein beneath the tongue after cephalic phlebotomy.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	The true method of phlebotomy concerning the two veins beneath the tongue: It is that phlebotomy of the cephalic vein should be performed for conditions in the throat, and for ailments of the uvula and disorders of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of performing phlebotomy is such that the patient should sit between your hands facing the sun; and raise his tongue, and look beneath his tongue at one vein from the side, and another vein from the other side; and the color of each should turn to blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Perform phlebotomy on both veins; and be careful not to use your last hand on the phlebotomy.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For beneath them are arteries, and perhaps there may be a flow of blood from these arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	On the three veins in the forearm.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	The three veins that are phlebotomized in the forearm—of these, phlebotomy of one is customary for all people.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	Phlebotomy of these should be performed according to two methods.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	By piercing with a myrtle-handled phlebotom; or by pressing with an olive-shaped instrument to achieve greater fluency; or by cutting with a surgical knife, it is called alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus is alnesil what pertains to incision.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from these there arise various broad and narrow kinds according to the width and tightness of the veins. The form of the myrtle phlebotom is wide as you can see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is used to open veins that are concave, full, swollen, visible, thick, and those that contain thick, cloudy blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this phlebotom is of smaller width and more delicate extremities.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is suitable for the delicate phlebotomy of veins containing thin, yellowish blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	**On phlebotomy of the basil (vein)**
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	However, the basil (vein), which is one of these three veins, provides the greatest facility for phlebotomy.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because he extracts blood from ailments that are under the throat and neck, following the chest and vein; and it is befitting for the phlebotomist to use a phlebotomy tool on it, as a precaution, and be above the fear of it, since there is an artery beneath it.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If, therefore, he errs and adds to the puncture of phlebotomy, he will hit that artery, and there will be a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore, it is necessary not to use a phlebotomy tool on it with a cutting phlebotomist; instead, it should be cut with an aluminium (or similar) instrument.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If it does not appear with a clear sign, then it is necessary to find others for it, and exchange it for another, or seek some branch of it; or apply a phlebotomy tool at the place of its position in the arm.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	Indeed, it is clear, and cut it with an aluminium phlebotomist, as we said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	However, if you wish to perform phlebotomy on the same site, then it is necessary before tightening the arm, to touch the place, until you know the location of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark the place with wax, afterwards tighten the arm, and cut the vein with a concave phlebotomist (as we said).
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And so that the blow does not fall through the space from the location of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see, as you tighten the ligament, an inflation at the place you indicated with wax, then that inflation is the inflation of the artery; therefore, release it gently.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	If you see blood rising during phlebotomy like urine from a boy, and it is thin, red blood, then know that it is from the artery's blood.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then proceed, and place your finger on the long space above, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If therefore blood is severed (it is often severed many times), then tighten the limb and release it; and let the patient be careful from its motion; and it should be over his fear.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And do not move it for several days until it heals.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	However, if the blood does not sever and it constricts you, and you do not have a remedy at hand, then cut the artery if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	Because its extremities are constricted, and the blood is severed.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Take and accept the leather of the fistula, and find its middle part; take one half and tighten it over the vein with a ligature and small stitches until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if the blood separates, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then take care of itself with that whose remembrance preceded the flow of blood from the place of the stitches; and the separation of the blood from it is not difficult in many dispositions, because of the small wound's location and the possibility of binding it from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	§ On the phlebotomy of the dark vein.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The dark veins, however, require a certain force for phlebotomy, which draws blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body; this is because it is composed of branches of the Basilic and Cephalic veins, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it happens that the phlebotomist should be careful because there is a nerve under it.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore he adds to the puncture of phlebotomy and finds a nerve, there is a loss of sensation, and its healing becomes difficult, and perhaps it does not heal completely.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve appears to the sense many times.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	If it is hidden in certain men and is subtle, and not shown, then you should put your phlebotomy where it passes through them, the incision with the alnessil, and the detachment of the nerves with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If the vein is between two nerves, then find the vein along its length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	**On the Cephalic Vein**
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	The phlebotomy of the cephalic vein is beneficial because it draws blood from the head and conveys it to the eye diseases.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And for this vein, if you wish, you should puncture it with a phlebotomizer made of olive or myrrh, because it is the healthiest of all veins, as it is neither beneath an artery nor a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	However, when you perform phlebotomy, it is necessary to remove the head of the vein only with a phlebotomizer, and look for a softer place, and it does not harm him if it is not found with the first strike, but it should be passed over it several times with phlebotomy.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	However, perhaps it will be displaced in some men when not phlebotomized in the first strike, but it does not harm him that displacement in some way.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	¶ On the usefulness of phlebotomy and precautions to be observed in it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	However, the quality of phlebotomy and its potential complications depend on careful consideration of the procedure's correct execution.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Firstly, it is essential to understand that phlebotomy should only be administered for the purpose of preserving health, and to continue doing so with caution to prevent illness from arising or worsening.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And phlebotomy should be performed on one of the three veins found in the arm, namely the cephalic, the femoral, or the basilic vein.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And to perform phlebotomy at the beginning of spring after fasting, on the veins located above the wrists, and in summer and winter after meals when there is a sign of overfullness.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And phlebotomy should be performed on the first or third day after three hours have passed since the previous day.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	However, phlebotomy performed to treat illness does not have a specific time; but when circumstances and necessity dictate, it can be done at night or during the day, and at any hour or time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not necessary for children under the age of fourteen to undergo phlebotomy until their veins become stronger.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	A pregnant woman should not have blood let from the fourth to the seventh month.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Nor should the elderly, who have already passed sixty years, be bled.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	So if anyone wishes to be bled for any reason, it is necessary that they cleanse their bowels before bloodletting with a gentle enema, if much feces is retained in them; so that the veins do not draw from the intestines an excess of putrid fluid harmful to the main members.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	A patient should not be bled when they are exhausted from nausea, nor constipated or too drunk until that condition is removed from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor should an invalid with edema be bled.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And let bloodletting be avoided again after a stomachache, vomiting, flow of the bowels, multiplication of coitus, labor, exercise, vigils, fasting, and anything else that weakens strength from the body or animal.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider the subtlety of the humors before that, if the blood is thick due to food, drink, and medicine; then it is possible for him to do that.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then he should take a bath, if nothing prohibits it; or exercise some kind of exercise to thin the blood.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And moreover, perform his phlebotomy about the third hour of the day, as we have said, and try to cause his chest to be drained on that day from all animal misfortunes, such as distress, anger, fear; and from all bodily misfortunes, such as labor, pain, excess, and similar ones.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let him make his condition present with those things of which usage is a custom among men, from aromatics and perfumery, and rejoicing, and similar ones, according to the possibility.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then the phlebotomist should sit on a bench higher than that of the patient; then he should draw his arm and rub it with the phlebotomist's hand twice or three times.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then he should tighten the ligature with the thong and wrap it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And the ligature should be firm, but not excessive, for when a ligature is uneven or there is too much tension in the ligature, it hinders the flow of blood; and similarly, when it is too loose, it also hinders the flow of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	After the ligature, he should then have the patient rub his hands gently back and forth until the veins swell and become visible to the touch.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the phlebotomist should cleanse the wound with a little oil, traditionally used for this purpose.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he should place his index finger of the left hand over the vein itself at the site where he intends to perform phlebotomy, lightly: so that the vein does not escape and is crushed.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	Since veins are like a cord that escapes during phlebotomy and some are full of swift blood flow; and when you place the phlebotomist over them, they contract beneath the phlebotomist and the phlebotomist is deceived, not opening the vein; and if he does open it, it is too tight. For this reason, it is necessary that the phlebotomist be firm and careful in all these matters.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then he should remove the phlebotomist.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If the vein opens on its own from the first attempt, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then repeat it another time at the same place lightly, or above it with haste; if the place does not heal.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	If the place heals or becomes weak, then release it on the day or after two days; and do not tie the ligature tightly.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps indeed the healing place attracts heat.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Nor should a bath be taken.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	He then practices phlebotomy if he loves it.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	If the opening is small or the blood flows gently, and you fear that too much blood might be lost, then repeat the phlebotomy in the same wound according to the right direction, and add only a little to the procedure.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do it quickly before the place is healed; for once the place is healed, it is a problem in many cases.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If therefore you see that the place is already healed, then do not repeat over it at all; for it does not allow you to achieve anything.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And place nothing on it from the fat of oil, for it eases the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better at this place than pure oil, and than all the rest of the oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And similarly, apply the fat of oil to every vein that you phlebotomize where there is a need to stop the flow of blood; and make it into a paste with flour and honey when applied to the place.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	Blood becomes thin and dissolves when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	If a great abscess occurs at the site of phlebotomy, which happens frequently, especially to those who have not been bled properly, or if there is only a small opening in the vein, then apply and place over the area a sponge soaked in water and salt, heated slightly, and squeeze it firmly immediately, as it will be relieved.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary that you do that after the blood has exited from the vein itself with its completion, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If after a few days there remains in the site some blackness or redness, it does not harm it; and if you wish, place over it something of aloe or myrrh dissolved, or something from the juice of mint, that is, warmth or something similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And indeed, abscesses and swellings often occur during phlebotomy in the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Therefore, place your hand over it, and if you feel softness at the time of your compression over it, then that swelling is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Therefore, put something over it from what we have said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood may flow from that artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make an embolism for it with what has constriction, so that the place hardens.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound itself with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary that you extract blood from every man according to the amount of his strength.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And that appears from the color rising above the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let it flow out until it turns red; and likewise, if you see it thick, then let it flow until it thins; and similarly, if it is acute, then remove its sharpness until it becomes smooth.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And he who is full, strong, and needs the extraction of blood at once, must have the vein amplified and be bled on the side, and conversely, for him who is weak.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary to extract the wound in vessels and make a tight opening; and better yet is that which is administered in vein phlebotomy, so that there is a transverse cut, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this mode of phlebotomy is safe from the flow of blood and from cutting a nerve; and it is more commendable and healthier than phlebotomy through width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And he who is accustomed to reach the point of phlebotomy with syncope, must give him a little bread soaked in pomegranate juice before phlebotomy, or warm water if he is heated; and extract blood from him in three or four places.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	If there is a chill in the complexion, then he should take bread soaked in thin syrup, or in syrup of honey perfumed with spices, or in perfumed aromatic syrup before phlebotomy.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If, during phlebotomy, a fainting spell occurs due to excessive blood loss, then one should take a drink of meat broth and thin aromatic syrup; they should use spices with the patient's chest and rest it; and employ the remedies mentioned in the chapter on syncope from evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	Whoever wishes to restore their arm and resolve their blood issues, if phlebotomy is required due to excessive evacuation and the patient's strength is weak, they should gradually dissolve their blood over several days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Indeed, whoever wishes to restore their arm and resolve their blood issues, but their body is strong, should do the following after seven or nine hours—or when it has been longer since their first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from their body towards the opposite part from where it is declining, should do so on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In cases where a person's body has too much already heated and aggravated blood, causing fever, it is necessary to draw out a significant amount of blood at once; and widen the opening until syncope occurs; after having preserved all conditions of phlebotomy; and place your hand over the pulse near the flow of blood, so as not to cause death in that spot.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	Many times this happens when the phlebotomist is ignorant, and it falls due to negligence.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not necessary when you intend to open the arm and second to let blood, while the opening of the vein is already closed, and it becomes difficult for the blood to flow out, as it is hurriedly superimposed on itself with impetuosity, and the wound quickly extends.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For that is a great evil, leave it alone for now, until it is bled a second time.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or remove with care the coagulated blood from the opening of the vein, and place over it some dissolved salt in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And place over it some of the alum or sage, and apply gentle compression until the blood flows out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If indeed the vein has already burst, then leave it, and do not press it, until the hematoma is seated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	If it is necessary to open the vein a second time and there is no excuse, then either bleed it again over that place, or on another arm in another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	The phlebotomy arm, however, at the place of the vein Fusca and Basilica, if they are not found and are hidden, since they are composed of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is such that the patient introduces his hand into warm water until the blade becomes red and the vein is clearly visible.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then it is tied over it with a thin ligature with moderate tightness.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then the phlebotomy is made according to the transverse direction gradually, not longitudinally or laterally, and your opening should be wide enough for the phlebotomy to be performed over the joint of the hand slightly.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If the flow of blood is obstructed, then repeat immersing your hand in warm water and allow the blood to flow into the water until you achieve your need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	However, if it is the summer season, then excuse yourself from immersing your hand in warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And certainly the most blood flow occurs in warm water during winter time.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And this vein's phlebotomy is the healthiest for all veins, because it is not pulsating under it nor is there a nerve.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	The phlebotomy of the left hand's Vein Saluatella is beneficial for liver ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of phlebotomy is such that you tighten the vein with your hand and ligature, or with your own hand, after you have inserted it into warm water, until the vein is bent and its sensation becomes very pronounced.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then perform the phlebotomy by passing it through.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut it completely through, it will not harm it in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And be careful not to use the phlebotomy tool too roughly.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	For under it are the naked nerves of the fingers, exposed from the flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then return your hand to the warm water and allow the blood to flow into it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not return it to warm water, the blood will coagulate in the vein's opening and be stopped from flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	So when you have withdrawn the necessary amount of blood, then place oil and salt on top of the vein, so that it does not clot quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And likewise, it is necessary that you do this with every branch tightly bound.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The true method of phlebotomy with the left hand is as follows: since it is directed towards the spleen's afflictions, do likewise in this phlebotomy as you did in the second equal manner.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The method for saphenous phlebotomy, however, is for ailments located in the lower part of the body, such as maladies of the matrix (uterine issues), retention of menses, kidney problems, old ulcers of the coxa and crura, and similar conditions from these ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is such that the patient immerses his afflicted foot in warm water, and makes friction over it until the veins burst, and ties above the joint of the foot with bindings.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And indeed, the veins are located near the calcaneum (heel bone), visible towards the thumb, and they branch out from it on the face of the foot with many branches.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Therefore, perform phlebotomy on it at the broader branch or near the calcaneum where it joins together, since this is better and healthier.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	Which if performing phlebotomy on it on the face of the foot, then be careful of the nerves that are under it on the surface of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And do not perform your phlebotomy through it as if you want to cut it, and let the phlebotomy be neat (precise).
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If, however, the escape of blood is forbidden, then repeat the procedure by immersing the foot in hot water and allow the blood to flow into it until it is cleared.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	If, however, the phlebotomist mistakes the vein in the first attempt, they should repeat the procedure higher up slightly, for that place is safe and there will be no harm from it when you seek relief from nerves, as we said before.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And likewise with the saphenous vein of the other foot.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The sciatic vein, as we said, is located at the side of the calf near the ankle.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the manner of phlebotomy for it is, to ease the pain of the ankle, when it is due to hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is that the patient should enter a warm bath and hurry: and grasp the foot with four fingers on the side of the ankle up to above the calcaneum, using a thin, long blade, for it is not visible otherwise.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When it appears, then perform the phlebotomy as best you can, either directly or according to the turn of the vein; and it is better, whether by making a cut with a blade or by slicing it with a section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For indeed it is a healthier place, and it is hidden from many men.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If you do not find it or it does not appear at all to the senses, then take a branch of it, which appears on the back of the foot and towards the ear, and cauterize from the nerves, causing blood to flow out in quantity as desired.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the stricture (bandage) and place over the site of the phlebotomy (bloodletting) a piece of skin, and tighten the area.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	Indeed, it heals quickly.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	**On Drainage (Ventilation) and the Nature of its Use**
Caput XCVIII.	Head 98.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Tents (wounds) are formed from horns, air, and other (foreign) bodies.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And Drainage (Ventilation) is performed according to two methods.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	When performing scraping and extraction of blood; and another is ventilation without scraping.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this ventilation which is without scraping (or incision) is according to two methods.
Aut enim est cum igne.	For indeed it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	For indeed it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the places where vapors are applied with cutting and extraction of blood are fourteen locations of the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	Of which one is the venting of the alnocratis, which is last on the head; and alkhel, which is in the middle of the neck; and the venting of the Alhagdahim, which are two layers on the neck from both sides; and the venting of the mind, which is under the jaw in the lower mouth; and the venting of the two spatulas; and the venting of the Alachosos, which is at the very end of the tail; and the venting of the two forks, which are in the middle of both arms; and the venting of the two tendons; and the venting of the two caves.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And indeed, venting does not extract blood from the small veins scattered in the flesh, and because of that, the strength does not leave them, as is the case with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Nor is it necessary to apply venting or with fire, or without fire, in any illness that results from fullness, until the whole body is emptied.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If need arises from illness to apply venting, or because of custom, we administer it at every hour at the beginning, end, and middle of the month, and at any time it may be.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	Which is because there are people who, when much blood accumulates in them, until it needs to be extracted through incision, find swelling and hardness in their head.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And from them, some find swelling and redness on their face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And from them, some experience itching on their face and forehead, darkness, and dullness in their eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And from them, some scratch the area of their incision.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And from them, some experience their laughter increasing.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And from them, some find the taste of blood in their mouth; or they might retch and spit out blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And from them, some experience prolonged sleep.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And from them, some see blood and redness in their sleep, wounds, and things similar to these.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When we therefore see something from these signs, and particularly if it occurs in the third medium of the month: we then order the incision to be made, after two or three hours have passed since sunset.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The treatment of venting the nape (of the neck) is as follows: since it conveys weight to the head and what drains towards the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	It is necessary at this point, so that it (the treatment) may be effective after the evacuation of the entire body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this, indeed, is the place for phlebotomy of the head.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it is not permissible to use it (the treatment) on one with a cold complexion or congestion.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it causes great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And because of this, it is not permissible to use (the treatment) on the elderly or those with cold-related ailments in their heads.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	However, if one insists on doing it (the treatment), oblivion will befall him.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And because of this, you should urge the ventosator to rest his hand with a gentle flow towards the lower parts, fearing the generation of oblivion.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Ventilation or alkehel is the place for the phlebotomy of the dusky (type of blood) and basic (phlebotomy), and because of this, it brings about asthma, constriction of the breath, cracking of the instrument, coughing, and fullness.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it is necessary that the ventosa (suction cup) be applied to Alkehel's wound momentarily, for if it is placed below, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	The use of the ventosa indeed provides relief from localized pain in the head, eyes, half-headache (hemigranae), perforation, and tooth root pain, and it takes the place of bloodletting with a leech.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And it is necessary that you warn the ventosa user not to use his hand for scraping too forcefully, so as not to cut an artery and cause bleeding.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	However, the use of the ventosa under the chin provides relief from alcohol in the mouth, decay of the gums, and similar conditions that affect the mouth, and it replaces other bloodletting methods on the lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	However, the use of ventosas in the form of spoons provides relief from arthritis, which is caused by stiffness and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	The use of ventosas on the internal parts of two bell-shaped cups provides assistance to bloodletting from three veins: the basilic, the fusca (dark vein), and the cephalic, because these ventosas draw blood from all those small veins in the flesh, and the smaller veins draw blood from the others until it reaches the three main veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And it is necessary that you warn the surgeon not to go too deep into the scarification, for the site is denuded of flesh, and beneath it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	However, the ventosa that is sucked over the anus helps with hemorrhoids and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And it is necessary that you instruct the surgeon that the ventosa should be strong and made of air, for the site needs a strong suction, and the delicate vents might break, so a deep scarification is required.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	However, the vents of the veins diminish their size visibly, for they draw blood from throughout the body, and bring relief to old pains in the kidneys, bladder, and gonads; they induce menstruation, relieve pain, and take the place of phlebotomy on two saphenous veins and varicose veins.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	However, they weaken the body greatly, and cause fainting in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And the aid of varicose veins is near to the aid of the two crusts' vents.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of the vents is that you place the ventosa first in a hollow place and apply a moderate suction; do not prolong the position of the vents, but remove them quickly, and move them quickly so that the humors reach the site with an equal flow; do not keep repeating this process and continuing until you see the site turning red and swollen, and appears to be blood-red: then scarify and repeat the suction gradually.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider the disposition of bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For those who have tender flesh, rare hair, it is necessary to perform the incision only once, not repeatedly, so as not to ulcerate the site.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And especially the windbagger, to amplify the incision, and make it deeper slightly; and regulate the suction for ease, speed, and his own motion.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is great thickness of blood, then it is necessary to perform the incision twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In the first instance, the path to thinning the blood and improving its flow is opened; and in the second, the precise examination for the meticulous extraction of thick blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If the blood is indeed very foul, then a third incision should be made; to achieve the ultimate result.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And finally, when we wish to extract blood gradually or in small amounts, a single incision is sufficient for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	Which if we wish to extract much blood, we perform many incisions.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure that the blood is thick: then it is necessary to make a deep incision; and the depth of the skin should be equal to the depth of the incision.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What is that which needs to be administered from oils at the site of the windpipes, and what should be avoided when using them?
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	In the case of skin that is thick, hard, and dark, with tight pores, it is necessary to apply the windpipe areas with open oils, such as lard, vegetable oil, or sweet almond oil, or pumpkin seed oil.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is during the winter season, then narcissus oil, or lily oil, or chamomile oil, or snowball (satina) oil, and similar oils.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If indeed there is excessive thick, cold moisture, then amber oil, or balsam oil, or white oil, or anise oil, and similar oils should be used.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	If indeed it is necessary to open wide the pores of tender flesh, then it should be prohibited from oil, and after ventilation, these windpipe areas should be washed with rosewater, or cold water, or warm water, or pumpkin seed water, or water from portulaca, and similar substances.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	He whose blood is excessively moist should wash the windpipes with vinegar or myrtle water and sumac, and similar substances.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	He should wash away their excess with old wine, or with pure water, or with anise or chamomile decoction, and similar substances.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it is necessary that ventilation be taken care of in the bath or in the bathing area; indeed, it is necessary to administer [a treatment] after leaving the bath, for an hour or two.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And it is not necessary for anyone to sleep after ventilation.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	§ What is it that is necessary to regulate ventilation or phlebotomy before ventilation?
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	And after that, you should consider primarily: if the one who is ventilated or bled is choleric, and acuteness and inflammation are present in his blood: then he should take cooling substances, such as the juice of a grenadine; and also throughout the day with vinegar and lettuce, and dry herbs, and fennel: and similar ones.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	And remove his food cravings for fat, and meat that is easily digested, and prepared foods with herbs: and similar ones.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	And for those whose condition is cold, it is necessary to take syrup in a drink of honey, or from almonds, or from fennel seeds made; and to consume medium perfumed wine, which is between old and new: and he should be instructed to limit his food intake.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	And remove his food and drink, and any vomit; and birds, that is, small birds; and the chicks of pigeons should be left.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And it is necessary that the drink on the day of cleansing and bloodletting be more than the food; and it is necessary to give in the drink for certain men in the hours of the tyro's ale, or a remedy from moss, that is, mace, or assafoetida before cleansing, or after: so that the principal members be strengthened, and the blood be thinned.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	And it is not necessary for them to take it in a hot drink.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	**On Wind (Pneumonia) without Scarification:**
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	However, the wind (pneumonia) that is without scarification affects the upper part of the epigastrium, and the spleen, and the podagra, and over the abdominal wall, and the navel, and the kidney locations, and the anchial pixels: for these members do not suffer scarification on themselves.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	And it is not sought through them unless there is an attraction from a member of blood to another member; as we place pneumonia over the nipples in the illness of nasal bleeding.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	And we use them to resolve the cold wind that has entered from one member to another; as we place a wind over the abdominal wall and navel.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	Indeed, it rarefies the member and warms it up, and thus drives away pain because it resolves that fluidity.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	It is also placed over the kidneys when there is a congestion or stone in them.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	By its powerful attraction, it may perhaps open up the congestion or even dislodge the stone from its position.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	And similarly, when placed over the spleen, it does the same, draining the blood from both of them.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	These wind passages are managed solely with incision.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	And sometimes they are managed with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	And sometimes they are administered with warm water in cases of pleurisy: and that is to fill the wind passage, making it large, with only hot water, or water in which herbs that are suitable are boiled.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	**Form of administering the wind passage with fire.**
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	It is the size of an opening between two fingers, shaped as we form it; its depth is halfway through the palm; and there is a small hole on its side, approximately in the middle, large enough for an awl to pass through: it should be made of iron or brass, smooth and flat, not damaging the member when placed above it; and in the center, there is a crossbar passing through it, made of iron or steel, where a candle with fire is placed.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	And now this becomes a great and swift flux, greater than we have described, and somewhat less according to the sickness and age of him who uses it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	For the winds of boys and those who are emaciated are different from the winds of men and of fat bodies.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.	The quality of applying this swift wind to a member over fire is such as kindling a nice flame with fire from linen or a small candle: and place it over the middle of the transverse staff that is in the center of the wind. So that the fire is ignited around the lower part of the wind, so as not to burn the weak body.
